revision.comment: Librairie does not mean library but bookshop in French. Library is "bibliothèque"
revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=January 2017}} {{Coord|32|3|2|N|118|46|24|E|display=title|name=Libraire Avant-Garde|format=dms}} {{Infobox company | name = Librairie Avant-Garde | image = Facade of Libraire Avant-Garde(Wutai Mountain branch).jpg | caption =The bookstore is housed in an underground parking lot on Guangzhou Road in Nanjing, China. | founded = {{start date | 1996| 11}} in [[Nanjing]], China | founder = Qian Xiaohua | hq_location = Nanjing, People's Republic of China | genre = Bookstore | products = books, handmade accessories, postcards, bags, notebooks | website = http://weibo.com/nanjingxianfeng?is_hot=1 https://site.douban.com/bookshop/ }}
'''Librairie Avant-Garde ([[Mount Wutai]] Branch)''' is a bookstore opened by [[Qian Xiaohua]] in 2004, now regarded as the most representative bookstore in [[Nanjing]], [[China]]. It has become a cultural icon of the city, and because of the adjacency to [[Nanjing University]] and the popularity among students, it is dubbed as "the second library of Nanjing University".
The bookshop is hidden in a former government parking lot underneath [[Wutaishan Stadium]], which has been used as a bomb shelter. Covering 3780 sq meter, it provides a large volume of social science and humanities books that have been recognized by the literati and history, ranging from [[literature]], [[history]], [[philosophy]], [[Film|movie]], [[music]], [[photography]], [[dance]], [[drama]], [[architecture]], [[art]], [[cartoon]] and [[Advertising|advertisement]] to [[social science]], [[business]] and [[journalism]], while excluding [[reference work]] and other practical books.
== Founding == After all the hardship of running the bookstore, bankruptcy in 2003 and the unpredictable, [[Qian Xiaohua]] restored energy and opened a flagship bookstore in an underground parking lot, on Guangzhou Road. Because at the time most friends of Qian were [[avant-garde]] writers, and he himself was an avid [[French literature]] lover, he named the bookstore Librairie Avant-Garde, in which Librairie is a French word that means bookshop. He hoped the bookstore could serve as a spiritual guide for the people making their way in darkness. "A good bookshop should provide space, vision and nurture the city with its humanitarian spirit," owner Qian Xiaohua tells CNN. "It's a place for people to have dreams in the city."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2015/08/03/travel/worlds-coolest-bookstores-new/|title=World's coolest bookstores|last=Cha|first=Frances|date=August 4, 2015|website=CNN Travel|publisher=CNN|access-date=January 26, 2017}}</ref> [[File:Librairie_Avant-garde_Inside_2012-06.JPG|thumb|400x400px|inside Librairie Avant-Garde]]
== Chronology == 1996: predecessor of Librairie Avant-Garde opened on Taiping South Road, across the road from [[St. Paul's Church(Nanjing)]], with a total area of mere 17 sq meter.
1999: moved to No.79, Guangzhou Road, next to the children's hospital, covering 97 sq meter.
2001: moved to No.12, Guangzhou Road, covering 600 sq meter.
2003: the first metro bookstore in Nanjing opened, at [[Xinjiekou Station (Nanjing)|Xinjiekou Station]]. [[Confucius temple|Confucius Temple]] Branch opened.
2004: [[Mount Wutai]] Branch opened.
2006: New City Square Branch opened.
2011: [[Presidential Palace (Nanjing)|Presidential Palace]] Branch opened.
2012: [[Wuxi]] Branch opened.
2013: [[Soong Mei-ling|May-ling]] Branch and Pioneer New Life Press opened.
2014: Lingyuan Road Branch(先锋永丰诗舍), Bishan Book Bureau and Runze Press opened.
2015: Jiangsu Road Branch, Yihe Academy and Yunxi Library opened.
2016: Laoqian Studio and Laomen East Branch opened.
== Other branches == Pioneer Literature&History Bookstore([[Sun Yat-sen Mausoleum|Presidential Palace]], No.292, [[Yangtze|Yangtze River]] Road, [[Nanjing]], [[Jiangsu]], [[China]])
Pioneer [[Republic of China (1912–49)|Republic of China]] Academy( Xijia Building, [[Presidential Palace (Nanjing)|Presidential Palace]], No.292, [[Yangtze|Yangtze River]] Road, [[Nanjing]], [[Jiangsu]], [[China]])
Pioneer Literature&History Bookstore([[Soong Mei-ling|May-ling]] Palace, [[Sun Yat-sen Mausoleum]], [[Nanjing]], [[Jiangsu]], [[China]])
Pioneer New Life Press([[Nanjing Museum]], No.321, Zhongshan East Road, [[Nanjing]], [[Jiangsu]], [[China]])
Librairie Avant-Garde(Lingyuan Road, [[Nanjing]], [[Jiangsu]], [[China]])
Pioneer Runze Press(No.86, Yushan West Road, [[Nanjing]], [[Jiangsu]], [[China]])
Pioneer Yihe Academy(No.39, Jiangsu Road, [[Nanjing]], [[Jiangsu]], [[China]])
Librairie Avant-Garde(Wuxi Branch)(No.186, Huishan Straight Street, [[Wuxi]], [[Jiangsu]], [[China]])
Bishan Book Bureau(Qitai Hall, [[Anhui]], [[China]])
Pioneer Yunxi Library(No.7, Mount Daijia, [[Zhejiang]], [[China]])
Laoqian Studio(No.189, Guangzhou Road, [[Nanjing]], [[Jiangsu]], [[China]])
Librairie Avant-Garde(Laomen East Branch)(Bianying No.2, [[Nanjing]], [[Jiangsu]], [[China]])
== Credits == [[File:Nanjing - Librairie Avant-Garde.jpg|center|thumb|panoramic view inside Librairie Avant-Garde]]
Librairie Avant-Garde is one of the world's most beautiful independent bookstores, listed by BBC in 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.com/culture/story/20140327-worlds-most-beautiful-bookshops|title=Ten of the world's most beautiful bookshops|website=BBC|publisher=BBC|last1=Fiona|first1=Macdonald|accessdate=16 January 2017}}</ref> Also rated as the most beautiful bookstore in China by CNN in 2015,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2013/09/02/travel/nanjing-book-shop/|title=China's most beautiful bookshop ... is in a parking lot|last=Wong|first=Liufu|date=November 19, 2015|website=CNN International Edition|publisher=CNN|access-date=January 23, 2017}}</ref> and in August, was listed in the coolest bookstores in the world.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2015/08/03/travel/worlds-coolest-bookstores-new/|title=World's coolest bookstores|last=Cha|first=Frances|date=August 4, 2015|website=CNN Travel|publisher=CNN|access-date=January 23, 2017}}</ref> The Librairie Avant-Garde is among the list ''[https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/mar/07/top-10-industrial-chic-restaurants-exhibition-spaces-architecture 10 of the best industrial-chic spaces worldwide]'' listed by [[The Guardian]] in 2016.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/mar/07/top-10-industrial-chic-restaurants-exhibition-spaces-architecture|title=10 of the best industrial-chic spaces worldwide|last=Coldwell|first=Will|date=March 7, 2016|website=Guardian Travel|publisher=The Guardian|access-date=January 23, 2017}}</ref>
== References == <references />
== External links == * https://site.douban.com/bookshop/
[[Category:Bookstores]]

page.title: List of World Heritage sites in Southern Europe

revision.text:
The [[UNESCO]] (United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization) has designated 168 [[World Heritage site]]s in all of the 15 sovereign countries (also called "[[Sovereign state|state parties]]") of [[Southern Europe]]: [[Albania]], [[Andorra]], [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]], [[Croatia]], [[Greece]], [[Italy]], [[Republic of Macedonia|Macedonia]], [[Malta]], [[Montenegro]], [[Portugal]], [[San Marino]], [[Serbia]], [[Slovenia]], [[Spain]], and [[Vatican City]] as well as one site in the [[British overseas territory]] of [[Gibraltar]].{{cite web | url = http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/&order=region | title = World Heritage List: Europe and North America | year = | work = | publisher = [[UNESCO]] | accessdate = 25 March 2017 }} While [[Cyprus]] and [[Turkey]] have territory in Southern Europe, they are not included here but in [[List of World Heritage Sites in Western Asia|Western Asia]]. The top two countries by number of World Heritage sites are located in this region: Italy with 53 sites and Spain with 46 sites (43 sites not including those on the Canary Islands). Seven sites are shared between several countries: [[Côa Valley Paleolithic Art|Prehistoric Rock Art Sites in the Côa Valley and Siega Verde]] (Portugal and Spain), [[Rhaetian Railway]] in the [[Albula Railway|Albula]] / [[Bernina railway|Bernina]] Landscapes (Italy and [[Switzerland]]), [[Monte San Giorgio]] (Italy and Switzerland), Historic Centre of [[Rome]], the Properties of the [[Holy See]] in that City Enjoying Extraterritorial Rights and [[San Paolo Fuori le Mura]] (Holy See and Italy), [[Pyrénées]] – [[Mont Perdu]] ([[France]] and Spain), [[Prehistoric Pile dwellings around the Alps]] ([[Austria]], France, [[Germany]], Italy, Slovenia and Switzerland) and [[Heritage of Mercury. Almadén and Idrija|Heritage of Mercury – Almadén and Idrija]] (Slovenia and Spain).{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list |title=World Heritage List |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=23 May 2013}} The first sites from the region were inscribed in 1979 a year after the list's conception, and included six sites in the former [[Yugoslavia]] and one site in Italy.{{Cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/pg.cfm?cid=31&l=en&action=stat&mode=table#s4 |title=Number of World Heritage properties inscribed each Year |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=8 September 2011}}{{Cite report |url=http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0003/000347/034793eb.pdf |format=PDF |title=Intergovernmental Committee for the Protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage, Second Session, Final Report |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |date=5–8 September 1978 |location=[[Washington, D.C.]] |pp=7–8 |accessdate=8 September 2011}} Each year, UNESCO's [[World Heritage Committee]] may inscribe new sites on the list, or delist sites that no longer meet the criteria. Selection is based on [[World Heritage Site#Selection criteria|ten criteria]]: six for [[cultural heritage]] (i–vi) and four for [[natural heritage]] (vii–x).{{Cite web|title=The Criteria for Selection |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/criteria |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=10 September 2011}} Some sites, designated "mixed sites," represent both cultural and natural heritage. In Southern Europe, there are 150 cultural, 12 natural, and 7 mixed sites. The World Heritage Committee may also specify that a site is [[World Heritage in Danger|endangered]], citing "conditions which threaten the very characteristics for which a property was inscribed on the World Heritage List." One of the sites ([[Medieval Monuments in Kosovo]]) in Southern Europe is listed as endangered and four sites ([[Old City of Dubrovnik]], [[Natural and Culturo-Historical Region of Kotor]], [[Plitvice Lakes National Park]] and [[Butrint]]) were previously listed. Possible danger listing has been considered by UNESCO in a number of other cases.{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/158/ |title=World Heritage in Danger |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=28 May 2010}}{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/decisions/247 |title=Decision - 28COM 15B.75 |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=23 October 2011}} ==Legend== The table is sortable by column by clicking on the [[File:Sort both.gif]] at the top of the appropriate column; alphanumerically for the Site, Area, and Year columns; by state party for the Location column; and by criteria type for the Criteria column. Transborder sites sort at the bottom. {{GeoGroupTemplate}} :'''Site'''; named after the World Heritage Committee's official designation :'''Location'''; at city, regional, or provincial level and geocoordinates :'''Criteria'''; as defined by the World Heritage Committee :'''Area'''; in [[hectare]]s and [[acre]]s. If available, the size of the buffer zone has been noted as well. A value of zero implies that no data has been published by UNESCO :'''Year'''; during which the site was inscribed to the World Heritage List :'''Description'''; brief information about the site, including reasons for qualifying as an endangered site, if applicable ==World Heritage sites== {{Legend|#D0E7FF|* Trans-border site|outline=silver}} {{Legend|#FFE6BD|† In danger|outline=silver}} {|class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" ! scope="col" | Site ! class="unsortable" style="width:150px;" scope="col"| Image ! scope="col" | Location ! scope="col" | [[World Heritage site#Selection criteria|Criteria]] ! scope="col"| Area
ha (acre) ! scope="col"| Year ! scope="col" class="unsortable" | Description |- ! scope="row" | 18th-Century Royal [[Palace at Caserta]] with the Park, the [[Aqueduct of Vanvitelli]], and the [[San Leucio]] Complex | [[File:Caserta, fuente de Diana y Acteón. 30.JPG|150x150px|alt=A row of water basins leading to a large palace building.]] | {{sort|Italy|Provinces of [[Province of Caserta|Caserta]] and [[Province of Benevento|Benevento]], [[Campania]], {{flag|Italy}}
{{coord|41|4|24|N|14|19|35|E|region:IT_type:landmark|name=18th-Century Royal Palace at Caserta with the Park, the Aqueduct of Vanvitelli, and the San Leucio Complex}}}} | Cultural:
(i)(ii)(iii)(iv) | {{convert|87|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}}; buffer zone {{convert|111|ha|abbr=values}} | align="center" | 1997 | {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/549|title=18th-Century Royal Palace at Caserta with the Park, the Aqueduct of Vanvitelli, and the San Leucio Complex|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=26 June 2010}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Acropolis of Athens|Acropolis]], Athens | [[File:View of the Acropolis Athens (pixinn.net).jpg|150x150px|alt=Ruins of a white temple with columns on a rock above a city.]] | {{sort|Greece|[[Attica (region)|Attica]], {{flag|Greece}}
{{coord|37|58|15|N|23|43|34|E|region:GR_type:landmark|name=Acropolis, Athens}}}} | Cultural:
(i)(ii)(iii)(iv)(vi) | {{convert|3.04|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}}; buffer zone {{convert|117|ha|abbr=values}} | align="center" | 1987 | A collection of massive, yet perfectly balanced architectural masterpieces in harmony with the natural landscape, the Acropolis of Athens is one of the most important expressions of Classical Greek aesthetics. It was completed by the 5th century BC and has since then exerted a profound influence on architecture worldwide.{{Cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/404|title=Acropolis, Athens|last=Centre|first=UNESCO World Heritage|website=whc.unesco.org|language=en|access-date=2016-09-07}} {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/404|title=Acropolis, Athens|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=26 June 2010}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Alhambra]], [[Generalife]] and [[Albayzín]], [[Granada]] | [[File:La Alhambra .jpg|150x150px|alt=A courtyard with a gallery and a basin supported by lion sculptures.]] | {{sort|Spain|[[Province of Granada]], [[Andalusia]], {{flag|Spain}}
{{coord|37|10|36|N|3|35|40|W|region:ES_type:landmark|name=Alhambra, Generalife and Albayzín, Granada}}}} | Cultural:
(i)(iii)(iv) | align="center" | — | align="center" | 1984Extended in 1994 to include the Albayzin neighborhood and name change from ''Alhambra and the Generalife, Granada'' to the present name. | The three sites are remnants of the [[Moors|Moorish]] influence in southern Spain. The fortress Alhambra and the palace Generalife were built by the rulers of the [[Emirate of Granada]]. The Albayzín district contains examples of the Moorish vernacular architecture and was added to the listing in 1994. {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/314|title=Alhambra, Generalife and Albayzín, Granada|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=20 December 2011}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Medina Azahara]], [[Córdoba, Spain|Córdoba]] | [[File:Edificio Basilical Superior de Medina Azahara (Córdoba, España).jpg|150x150px|alt="Upper basilical hall" or "Dar al-Jund", perhaps for administration.]] | {{sort|Spain|[[Province of Córdoba (Spain)|Province of Cordoba]], [[Andalusia]], {{flag|Spain}}
{{coord|37|53|10|N|4|52|04|W|region:ES_type:landmark|name=Medina Azahara, Cordoba}}}} | Cultural:
(i)(iii)(iv) | align="center" | — | align="center" | 2018 | Ruins of a vast, fortified Arab Muslim medieval palace-city built by Abd-ar-Rahman III (912–961), the first Umayyad Caliph of Córdoba, and located on the western outskirts of Córdoba, Spain.{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1560|title=Caliphate City of Medina Azahara|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=2 July 2018}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Alto Douro Wine Region]] | [[File:Douro, Vinha e Vasilhas.jpg|150x150px|alt=A river with terraced vineyards.]] | {{sort|Portugal|[[Douro Subregion]], [[Trás-os-Montes e Alto Douro Province]], {{flag|Portugal}}
{{coord|41|6|6|N|7|47|56|W|region:PT_type:landmark|name=Alto Douro Wine Region}}}} | Cultural:
(iii)(iv)(v) | {{convert|24600|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}}; buffer zone {{convert|225400|ha|abbr=values}} | align="center" | 2001 | {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1046|title=Alto Douro Wine Region|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=26 June 2010}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Arab-Norman Palermo and the Cathedral Churches of Cefalù and Monreale|Arab–Norman Palermo and the Cathedral Churches of Cefalú and Monreale]] | [[File:Palermo-San-Cataldo-bjs-1.jpg|150x150px]] | {{sort|Sicily|[[Province of Palermo]], [[Sicily]], {{flag|Italy}}
{{coord|38|6|39|N|13|21|11|E|region:IT_type:landmark|name=Arab-Norman Palermo and the Cathedral Churches of Cefalú and Monreale}}}} | | Cultural:
(ii)(iv) | {{convert|6.24|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}}; buffer zone {{convert|483|ha|abbr=values}} | align="center" | 2015 | The new Norman rulers started to build various constructions in what is called the Arab-Norman style. They incorporated the best practices of Arab and Byzantine architecture into their own art.”Le genie architectural des Normands a su s’adapter aux lieux en prenant ce qu’il y a de meilleur dans le savoir-faire des batisseurs arabes et byzantins”, ''Les Normands en Sicile'', p.14{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1487|title=Arab-Norman Palermo and the Cathedral Churches of Cefalú and Monreale|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=13 November 2017}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Aranjuez Cultural Landscape]] | [[File:Palacio Real de Aranjuez - 130921 115527.jpg|150x150px|alt=A large palace building with white and orange walls.]] | {{sort|Spain|[[Aranjuez]], [[Community of Madrid]], {{flag|Spain}}
{{coord|40|2|11|N|3|36|34|W|region:ES_type:landmark|name=Aranjuez Cultural Landscape}}}} | Cultural:
(ii)(iv) | {{convert|2048|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}}; buffer zone {{convert|16605|ha|abbr=values}} | align="center" | 2001 | The landscape around the [[Royal Palace of Aranjuez]] was developed by the Spanish royal family over a course of three centuries and contains innovative horticultural and design ideas. The area was the exclusive property of the royal family until the 19th century when the modern civilian city developed. {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1044|title=Aranjuez Cultural Landscape|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=20 December 2011}} |- ! scope="row" | Archaeological Area and the Patriarchal Basilica of [[Aquileia]] | [[File:Aqui-ost.JPG|150x150px|alt=Roman stone church.]] | {{sort|Italy|[[Province of Udine]], [[Friuli-Venezia Giulia]], {{flag|Italy}}
{{coord|45|46|6|N|13|22|3|E|region:IT_type:landmark|name=Archaeological Area and the Patriarchal Basilica of Aquileia}}}} | Cultural:
(iii)(iv)(vi) | {{convert|155|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}} | align="center" | 1998 | {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/825|title=Archaeological Area and the Patriarchal Basilica of Aquileia|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=26 June 2010}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Archaeological Area of Agrigento]] | [[File:Valle dei templi (tone-mapping) II.jpg|150x150px|alt=Ruins of a classical temple with columns.]] | {{sort|Italy|[[Province of Agrigento]], [[Sicily]], {{flag|Italy}}
{{coord|37|17|23|N|13|35|36|E|region:IT_type:landmark|name=Archaeological Area of Agrigento}}}} | Cultural:
(i)(ii)(iii)(iv) | {{convert|934|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}}; buffer zone {{convert|1869|ha|abbr=values}} | align="center" | 1997 | {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/831|title=Archaeological Area of Agrigento|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=26 June 2010}} |- ! scope="row" | Archaeological Areas of [[Pompeii|Pompei]], [[Herculaneum]] and [[Oplontis|Torre Annunziata]] | [[File:Ancient Roman Pompeii - Pompeji - Campania - Italy - July 10th 2013 - 32.jpg|150x150px|alt=A street with ruined houses.]] | {{sort|Italy|[[Province of Naples]], [[Campania]], {{flag|Italy}}
{{coord|40|45|0|N|14|29|0|E|region:IT_type:landmark|name=Archaeological Areas of Pompei, Herculaneum and Torre Annunziata}}}} | Cultural:
(iii)(iv)(v) | {{convert|98|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}}; buffer zone {{convert|24|ha|abbr=values}} | align="center" | 1997 | {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/829|title=Archaeological Areas of Pompei, Herculaneum and Torre Annunziata|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=26 June 2010}} |- ! scope="row" | Archaeological Ensemble of [[Tarraco|Tárraco]] | [[File:Amphitheatre of Tarragona 01.jpg|150x150px|alt=Ruins of an amphitheatre near the sea.]] | {{sort|Spain|[[Province of Tarragona]], [[Catalonia]], {{flag|Spain}}
{{coord|41|6|53|N|1|15|34|E|region:ES_type:landmark|name=Archaeological Ensemble of Tárraco}}}} | Cultural:
(ii)(iii) | {{convert|100|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}} | align="center" | 2000 | The prominent Roman city of Tárraco at the site of modern-day Tarragona served as the capital of the provinces of [[Hispania Citerior]] and later [[Hispania Tarraconensis]]. The [[Tarragona Amphitheatre|amphitheatre]] was constructed in the 2nd century. Most remains are only fragments or preserved under more modern buildings. {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/875rev|title=Archaeological Ensemble of Tárraco|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=20 December 2011}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Archaeological Ensemble of Mérida]] | [[File:Teatro Romano de Mérida (Badajoz, España) 02.jpg|150x150px|alt=Ruins of an amphitheatre near the sea.]] | {{sort|Spain|[[Province of Badajoz]], [[Extremadura]], {{flag|Spain}}
{{coord|38|54|58|N|6|20|16|W|region:ES_type:landmark|name=Archaeological Ensemble of Mérida}}}} | Cultural:
(iii)(iv) | align="center" | — | align="center" | 1993 | Mérida was founded in 25 BC by the Romans as ''Emerita Augusta'' and was the capital of the [[Lusitania]] province. Remains from the Roman era include a [[Puente Romano (Mérida)|bridge]], [[Acueducto de los Milagros|aqueduct]], [[Mérida amphitheatre|amphitheatre]], [[Roman theatre (Mérida)|theatre]], [[Circus Maximus (Mérida)|circus]], and [[Roman Forum (Mérida)|forum]]. {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/664|title=Archaeological Ensemble of Mérida|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=20 December 2011}} |- ! scope="row" | Archaeological Site of Aigai (modern name [[Vergina]]) | [[File:Facade of Philip II tomb Vergina Greece.jpg|150x150px|alt=Facade of an underground structure with a painting above the door.]] | {{sort|Greece|[[Imathia]], [[Central Macedonia]], {{flag|Greece}}
{{coord|40|28|17|N|22|19|6|E|region:GR_type:landmark|name=Archaeological Site of Aigai (modern name Vergina)}}}} | Cultural:
(i)(iii) | {{convert|1421|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}}; buffer zone {{convert|4812|ha|abbr=values}} | align="center" | 1996 | The ancient city of [[Aegae (Macedon)|Aigai]] was the first capital of the Kingdom of [[Macedon]]. In addition to the monumental palace, lavishly decorated with mosaics and painted stuccoes, the site contains a burial ground with more than 300 tumuli, one of which has been identified as that of [[Philip II of Macedon]], father of [[Alexander the Great]].{{Cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/780|title=Archaeological Site of Aigai (modern name Vergina)|last=Centre|first=UNESCO World Heritage|website=whc.unesco.org|language=en|access-date=2016-09-07}} {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/780|title=Archaeological Site of Aigai (modern name Vergina)|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=26 June 2010}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Archaeological Site of Atapuerca]] | {{center|[[File:Dolina-Pano-3.jpg|150x150px|alt=Archaeological excavation site in red earth.]]}} | {{sort|Spain|[[Province of Burgos]], [[Castile and León]], {{flag|Spain}}
{{coord|42|22|17|N|3|32|50|W|region:ES_type:landmark|name=Archaeological Site of Atapuerca}}}} | Cultural:
(iii)(v) | align="center" | — | align="center" | 2000 | The caves in the Atapuerca Mountains contain fossil remains of the earliest human beings discovered in Europe dating from nearly one million years ago. The ''Sima de los Huesos'' or "Pit of Bones" contains the world's largest collection of hominid fossils. {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/989|title=Archaeological Site of Atapuerca|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=20 December 2011}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Archaeological Site of Delphi]] | [[File:Delphi Composite.jpg|150x150px|alt=Ruins of an amphitheatre in a mountain landscape.]] | {{sort|Greece|[[Phocis]], [[Central Greece (region)|Central Greece]], {{flag|Greece}}
{{coord|38|28|53|N|22|29|46|E|region:GR_type:landmark|name=Archaeological Site of Delphi}}}} | Cultural:
(i)(ii)(iii)(iv)(vi) | {{convert|51|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}}; buffer zone {{convert|14314|ha|abbr=values}} | align="center" | 1987 | The pan-Hellenic sanctuary of [[Delphi]], location of the [[Pythia|oracle]] of [[Apollo]], was the spiritual center of the Greek world. Situated in a spectacular natural setting at the foot of [[Mount Parnassus]], it was a symbol of Greek cultural unity from the 8th century BC onwards.{{Cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/393|title=Archaeological Site of Delphi|last=Centre|first=UNESCO World Heritage|website=whc.unesco.org|language=en|access-date=2016-09-07}} {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/393|title=Archaeological Site of Delphi|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=26 June 2010}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Archaeological Site of Mystras]] | {{center|[[File:GR-mystras-oberstadt-treppen.jpg|150x150px|alt=A complex of buildings partially in ruins in a mountain landscape.]]}} | {{sort|Greece|[[Laconia]], [[Peloponnese (region)|Peloponnese]], {{flag|Greece}}
{{coord|37|4|50|N|22|22|0|E|region:GR_type:landmark|name=Archaeological Site of Mystras}}}} | Cultural:
(ii)(iii)(iv) | {{convert|54|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}}; buffer zone {{convert|1203|ha|abbr=values}} | align="center" | 1989 | Long known as "the Wonder of the [[Morea]]", the remarkably well-preserved medieval city of Mystras played a central role in the final years of the [[Byzantine Empire]]. Built on a steep hill at the foot of Mount [[Taygetus]], it was the last Byzantine stronghold to fall to the [[Ottoman Empire|Ottomans]], holding out until 1461.{{Cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/511|title=Archaeological Site of Mystras|last=Centre|first=UNESCO World Heritage|website=whc.unesco.org|language=en|access-date=2016-09-07}} {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/511|title=Archaeological Site of Mystras|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=26 June 2010}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Archaeological Site of Olympia]] | [[File:Olympie Temple Zeus.JPG|150x150px|alt=Ruins of buildings and a column.]] | {{sort|Greece|[[Elis (regional unit)|Elis]], Western [[Peloponnese]], {{flag|Greece}}
{{coord|37|39|0|N|21|40|0|E|region:GR_type:landmark|name=Archaeological Site of Olympia}}}} | Cultural:
(i)(ii)(iii)(iv)(vi) | {{convert|106|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}}; buffer zone {{convert|1458|ha|abbr=values}} | align="center" | 1989 | The site of Olympia, built on the banks of the [[Alpheios]] river in the [[Peloponnese]], was the location of the [[ancient Olympic Games]] beginning in 776 BC. In addition to numerous temples and sanctuaries, it contains the remains of several sporting structures, such as its famous stadium.{{Cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/517|title=Archaeological Site of Olympia|last=Centre|first=UNESCO World Heritage|website=whc.unesco.org|language=en|access-date=2016-09-07}} {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/517|title=Archaeological Site of Olympia|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=26 June 2010}} |- ! scope="row" | Archaeological Sites of [[Mycenae]] and [[Tiryns]] | [[File:Lions-Gate-Mycenae.jpg|150x150px|alt=A gate of stone with a relief of two four legged animals.]] | {{sort|Greece|[[Argolis]], [[Peloponnese]], {{flag|Greece}}
{{coord|37|44|0|N|22|45|0|E|region:GR_type:landmark|name=Archaeological Sites of Mycenae and Tiryns}}}} | Cultural:
(i)(ii)(iii)(iv)(vi) | align="center" | — | align="center" | 1999 | Mycenae and Tiryns were two of the most important cities of [[Mycenean Greece]], which flourished between the 15th and 12th centuries BC. The [[Lion's Gate]] and [[Treasury of Atreus]] at Mycenae have been listed as "outstanding examples of human creative genius".{{Cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/941|title=Archaeological Sites of Mycenae and Tiryns|last=Centre|first=UNESCO World Heritage|website=whc.unesco.org|language=en|access-date=2016-09-07}} {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/941|title=Archaeological Sites of Mycenae and Tiryns|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=26 June 2010}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Assisi]], the [[Basilica of San Francesco d'Assisi|Basilica of San Francesco]] and Other Franciscan Sites | [[File:Basilica.Francis04.jpg|150x150px|alt=A white church with a white tower next to it.]] | {{sort|Italy|{{flag|Italy}}

(ii)(iii)(iv)(vi) | {{convert|351|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}} | align="center" | 1990 | The birthplace of [[Apollo]] and [[Artemis]] according to Greek mythology, the sacred island of Delos was one of the most important pan-Hellenic sanctuaries. The sanctuary of Apollo on Delos attracted pilgrims from all over Greece, making Delos a prosperous trading port.{{Cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/530|title=Delos|last=Centre|first=UNESCO World Heritage|website=whc.unesco.org|language=en|access-date=2016-09-07}} {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/530|title=Delos|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=26 June 2010}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Doñana National Park]] | [[File:Wetlands in Donana.jpg|150x150px|alt=Wetlands with birds.]] | {{sort|Spain|[[Province of Huelva|Huelva]] and [[Province of Sevilla|Seville]] Provinces, [[Andalusia]], {{flag|Spain}}

(vii)(ix)(x) | {{convert|54252|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}} | align="center" | 1994Extended in 2005 to bring the property in line with the extended National Park. | The park consists of the delta region where the [[Guadalquivir River]] reaches the [[Atlantic Ocean]]. It is home to a diverse variety of [[biotope]]s, such as [[lagoon]]s, [[marsh]]lands, [[dunes]], and [[Maquis shrubland|maquis]]. The park is one of the largest [[heronry|heronries]] in the [[Mediterranean Sea|Mediterranean]] region and holds more than 500,000 [[water fowl]] during the winter period. {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/685|title=Doñana National Park|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=20 December 2011}}

(vii), (ix) || align="center" | {{convert|3984|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}} || align="center" | 1986 || Most of the park, in the middle of the island of La Gomera of the [[Canary Islands]], is covered with a lush [[laurel forest]].{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/380 |title=Garajonay National Park |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=28 May 2010}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Garrison Border Town of Elvas and its Fortifications]] | [[File:ElvasSquare.jpg|150x150px|alt=Ramparts of Elvas.]] | {{sort|Portugal|[[Alentejo]], {{flag|Portugal}}
{{coord|38|52|50|N|7|9|48|W|region:PT_type:landmark|name=Garrison Border Town of Elvas and its Fortifications}}}} | Cultural:
(iv) | {{convert|179|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}}; buffer zone {{convert|608|ha|abbr=values}} | align="center" | 2012 | The site, extensively fortified from the 17th to 19th centuries, represents the largest bulwarked dry ditch system in the work. Within its walls, the town contains barracks and other military buildings as well as churches and monasteries. While Elvas contains remains dating back to the 10th century A.D., its fortification began when Portugal regained independence in 1640. The fortifications designed by Dutch Jesuit Padre João Piscásio Cosmander represent the best surviving example of the Dutch school of fortifications anywhere. The site also contains the Amoreira Aqueduct, built to enable the stronghold to withstand lengthy sieges. {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1367|title=Garrison Border Town of Elvas and its Fortifications|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=2 July 2012}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Gamzigrad-Romuliana]], Palace of Galerius | [[File:Felix Romuliana 8.jpg|150x150px|alt=Ruins of a building with columns.]] | {{sort|Serbia|[[Moravian Banovina|Eastern Serbia]], {{flag|Serbia}}
{{coord|43|53|57.5|N|22|11|10|E|region:RS_type:landmark|name=Gamzigrad-Romuliana, Palace of Galerius}}}} | Cultural:
(iii)(iv) | {{convert|179|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}}; buffer zone {{convert|545|ha|abbr=values}} | align="center" | 2007 | The Late Roman fortified palace compound and memorial complex of Gamzigrad-Romuliana, Palace of [[Galerius]], in the east of Serbia, was commissioned by Emperor Caius Valerius Galerius Maximianus, in the late 3rd and early 4th centuries. It was known as Felix Romuliana, named after the emperor’s mother. The site consists of fortifications, the palace in the north-western part of the complex, basilicas, temples, hot baths, memorial complex, and a tetrapylon. The group of buildings is also unique in its intertwining of ceremonial and memorial functions. {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1253|title=Gamzigrad-Romuliana, Palace of Galerius|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=26 June 2010}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Genoa]]: ''Le Strade Nuove'' and the system of the ''[[Palazzi dei Rolli]]'' | {{centre|[[File:Centre et vieille-ville Gênes 1854 (8195511417).jpg|150x150px|alt=Narrow street lined by four storied buildings.]]}} | {{sort|Italy|[[Province of Genoa]], [[Liguria]], {{flag|Italy}}

(ii)(iii)(iv) | {{convert|21|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}} | align="center" | 1979 | The palace was built by the Roman emperor [[Diocletian]] at the turn of the fourth century AD, and later served as the basis of the city of Split. A cathedral was built in the Middle Ages inside the ancient mausoleum, along with churches, fortifications, Gothic and Renaissance palaces. The Baroque style makes up the rest of the area. {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/97|title=Historical Complex of Split with the Palace of Diocletian|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=26 June 2011}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Historic Centre of Cordoba]] | [[File:Cordoba-Puente Romano02.jpg|150x150px|alt=Dense city centre with white houses and a large church or palace complex.]] | {{sort|Spain|[[Province of Córdoba (Spain)|Province of Córdoba]], [[Andalusia]], {{flag|Spain}}

(i)(ii)(vi) | align="center" | — | align="center" | 1986 | Toledo was founded by the Romans, served as the capital of the [[Visigothic Kingdom]], was important in [[Caliphate of Córdoba|Muslim Spain]] and during the [[Reconquista]], and briefly served as the capital of Spain. The city combines Christian, Muslim, and [[History of the Jews in Spain|Jewish]] influences. {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/379|title=Historic City of Toledo|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=20 December 2011}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Historic City of Trogir]] | [[File:Trogir3.jpg|150x150px|alt=Coastal town with a palm tree promenade and houses with red roofs.]] | {{sort|Croatia|[[Split-Dalmatia County]], {{flag|Croatia}}
{{coord|43|30|45|N|16|15|6|E|region:HR_type:landmark|name=Historic City of Trogir}}}} | Cultural:
(ii)(v) | {{convert|6.40|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}}; buffer zone {{convert|4.80|ha|abbr=values}} | align="center" | 1997 | Trogir's rich culture was created under the influence of old Greeks, Romans, and Venetians. It is the best-preserved Romanesque-[[Gothic architecture|Gothic]] complex not only in the Adriatic, but in all of Central Europe. Trogir's medieval core, surrounded by walls, comprises a preserved castle and tower and a series of dwellings and palaces from the Romanesque, Gothic, Renaissance and Baroque periods. {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/810|title=Historic City of Trogir|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=11 November 2017}} |- ! scope="row" | Historic Walled Town of [[Cuenca, Spain|Cuenca]] | [[File:007253 - Cuenca (8675297263).jpg|150x150px|alt=Town built on a rocky cliff.]] | {{sort|Spain|[[Province of Cuenca (Spain)|Province of Cuenca]], [[Castile–La Mancha]], {{flag|Spain}}
{{coord|40|4|36|N|2|7|54|W|region:ES_type:landmark|name=Historic Walled Town of Cuenca}}}} | Cultural:
(ii)(v) | align="center" | — | align="center" | 1996 | The Moors built the fortified city in the early 8th century, and it was captured by the Christians in the 12th century. The cathedral is the first [[Gothic architecture|Gothic]] example in Spain. The town is also famous for its ''casas colgados'', houses that hang over the edge of a cliff. {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/781|title=Historic Walled Town of Cuenca|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=20 December 2011}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Ibiza]], Biodiversity and Culture | [[File:Aerial view of the island of Sa Conillera, near St. Antoni de Portmany.jpg|150x150px|alt=]] | {{sort|Spain|[[Balearic Islands]], {{flag|Spain}}

(i)(ii)(iii)(iv) | align="center" | — | align="center" | 1997 | The Romans established a gold mine and worked the site for two centuries. They used an early form of [[hydraulic mining]] and cut aqueducts in the rock cliffs to provide water for the operations. The Romans left in the early 3rd century, leaving sheer cliff faces and mining infrastructure that is intact today. {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/803|title=Las Médulas|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=20 December 2011}} |- ! scope="row" | Late Baroque Towns of the [[Val di Noto]] (South-Eastern Sicily) | {{center|[[File:Catania 2846.jpg|150x150px|alt=White baroque church.]]}} | {{sort|Italy|Provinces of [[Province of Catania|Catania]], [[Province of Ragusa|Ragusa]] and [[Province of Syracuse|Syracuse]], [[Sicily]], {{flag|Italy}}

(ii)(iv)(v) | {{convert|66|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}} | align="center" | 1988 | The [[Order of St John of Jerusalem]] occupied [[Rhodes]] from 1309 to 1523 and set about transforming the city into a stronghold. It subsequently came under Turkish and Italian rule. With the [[Palace of the Grand Master of the Knights of Rhodes|Palace of the Grand Masters]], the Great Hospital and the Street of the Knights, the Upper Town is one of the most beautiful urban ensembles of the [[Gothic art|Gothic period]]. In the Lower Town, Gothic architecture coexists with mosques, public baths and other buildings dating from the [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] period.{{Cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/493|title=Medieval City of Rhodes|last=Centre|first=UNESCO World Heritage|website=whc.unesco.org|language=en|access-date=2016-09-07}} {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/493|title=Medieval City of Rhodes|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=26 June 2010}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Medici villas|Medici Villas and Gardens in Tuscany]] | [[File:Villa medici di belcanto, villa inferiore 02.JPG|150x150px|alt=]] | {{sort|Italy|[[Tuscany]], {{flag|Italy}}
{{coord|43|51|28|N|11|18|15|E|region:IT_type:landmark|name=Medici Villas and Gardens in Tuscany}}}} | Cultural:
(ii)(iv)(vi) | {{convert|125|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}}; buffer zone {{convert|3539|ha|abbr=values}} | align="center" | 2013 | {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/175|title=Medici Villas and Gardens in Tuscany|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=4 August 2013}} |-style="background-color: #FFE6BD" ! scope="row" style="background-color: #FFE6BD" | [[Medieval Monuments in Kosovo]] | [[File:Манастир Грачаница.jpg|150x150px|alt=Stone church with various towers.]] | [[Kosovo]],{{Kosovo-note}} officially listed as {{sort|Serbia|[[Autonomous Province of Kosovo]], {{flag|Serbia}}
{{coord|42|39|40|N|20|15|56|E|region:RS_type:landmark|name=Medieval Monuments in Kosovo}}}} | Cultural:
(ii)(iii)(iv) | {{convert|2.88|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}}; buffer zone {{convert|115|ha|abbr=values}} | align="center" | 2004Extended in 2006 to include the [[Patriarchal Monastery of Peć]], the [[Gračanica monastery]] and [[Our Lady of Ljeviš]]. Name change from ''[[Dečani Monastery]]'' to the present name. | The four edifices of the site reflect the high points of the Byzantine-Romanesque ecclesiastical culture, with its distinct style of wall painting, which developed in the Balkans between the 13th and 17th centuries. The Dečani Monastery was built in the mid-14th century for the Serbian king Stefan Dečanski and is also his mausoleum. The [[Patriarchal Monastery of Peć]] is a group of four domed churches featuring series of wall paintings. The 13th-century frescoes of the Church of Holy Apostles are painted in a unique, monumental style. Early 14th-century frescoes in the church of the Holy Virgin of Ljevisa represent the appearance of the new so-called Palaiologian Renaissance style, combining the influences of the eastern Orthodox Byzantine and the Western Romanesque traditions. The style played a decisive role in subsequent Balkan art. The site has been listed as [[World Heritage in Danger|endangered]] since 2006 due to a lack of legal protection and management; political instability and security. {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/724|title=Medieval Monuments in Kosovo|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=26 June 2010}}

(i)(ii)(iv)(v)(vii) | {{convert|272|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}}; buffer zone {{convert|1884|ha|abbr=values}} | align="center" | 1988 | In a region of almost inaccessible sandstone peaks, monks settled on these 'columns of the sky' from the 11th century onwards. Twenty-four of these monasteries were built, despite incredible difficulties, at the time of the great revival of the [[eremetic]] ideal in the 15th century. Their 16th-century frescoes mark a key stage in the development of [[Post-Byzantine art|post-Byzantine]] painting.{{Cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/455|title=Meteora|last=Centre|first=UNESCO World Heritage|website=whc.unesco.org|language=en|access-date=2016-09-07}} {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/455|title=Meteora|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=26 June 2010}} |- ! scope="row" | Monasteries of [[Daphni Monastery|Daphni]], [[Hosios Loukas]] and [[Nea Moni of Chios]] | {{center|[[File:GR-osios-loukas-barbara-kap.jpg|150x150px|alt=Mosaic of a baptemn.]]}} | {{sort|Greece|[[Attica (region)|Attica]], [[Central Greece (region)|Central Greece]] and [[North Aegean]], {{flag|Greece}}
{{coord|38|24|0|N|22|45|0|E|region:GR_type:landmark|name=Monasteries of Daphni, Hosios Loukas and Nea Moni of Chios}}}} | Cultural:
(i)(iv) | {{convert|3.70|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}}; buffer zone {{convert|5816|ha|abbr=values}} | align="center" | 1990 | Although geographically distant from each other, these three monasteries belong to the same typological series and share the same aesthetic characteristics. The churches are built on a cross-in-square plan with a large dome supported by squinches defining an octagonal space. In the 11th and 12th centuries they were decorated with superb marble works as well as mosaics on a gold background, all characteristic of the 'second golden age of [[Byzantine art]]'.{{Cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/537|title=Monasteries of Daphni, Hosios Loukas and Nea Moni of Chios|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=UNESCO|access-date=2012-09-30}} {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/537|title=Monasteries of Daphni, Hosios Loukas and Nea Moni of Chios|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=26 June 2010}} |- ! scope="row" | [[El Escorial|Monastery and Site of the Escorial, Madrid]] | [[File:El Monasterio de San Lorenzo de El Escorial.JPG|150x150px|alt=A large building complex with towers.]] | {{sort|Spain|[[San Lorenzo de El Escorial]], [[Community of Madrid]], {{flag|Spain}}

(i)(ii)(iv)(v)(vi)(vii) | {{convert|33042|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}} | align="center" | 1988 | An Orthodox spiritual centre since 1054, Mount Athos has enjoyed an autonomous statute since[[Byzantine]] times. The 'Holy Mountain', which is forbidden to women and children, is also a recognized artistic site. The layout of the monasteries (about 20 of which are presently inhabited by some 1,400 monks) had an influence as far afield as [[Russia]], and its school of painting influenced the history of Orthodox art.{{Cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/454|title=Mount Athos|last=Centre|first=UNESCO World Heritage|website=whc.unesco.org|language=en|access-date=2016-09-08}} {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/454|title=Mount Athos|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=26 June 2010}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Mount Etna]] | [[File:Taormina 03 10 04.JPG|150x150px|alt=]] | {{sort|Italy|[[Sicily]], {{flag|Italy}}

(i)(iii)(iv) | {{convert|97|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}}; buffer zone {{convert|54|ha|abbr=values}} | align="center" | 1979Extended in 1994. | Dubrovnik became a prosperous [[Maritime republics|Maritime republic]] during the Middle Ages, it became the only eastern Adriatic city-state to rival Venice. Supported by its wealth and skilled diplomacy, the city achieved a remarkable level of development, particularly during the 15th and 16th centuries. The site had been listed as [[World Heritage in Danger]] 1991–1998 due to the [[Croatian War of Independence]]. {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/95|title=Old City of Dubrovnik|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=26 June 2011}}
{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/archive/1991/sc-91-conf002-15e.pdf|format=PDF |title=World Heritage Committee: Fifteenth session |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=26 June 2011|page=31}}
{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/archive/1998/whc-98-conf203-18e.pdf|format=PDF |title=World Heritage Committee: Twenty-second session |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=26 June 2011|pages=12–13}} |- ! scope="row" | Old City of [[Salamanca]] | [[File:Approaching the cathedral via patio chico.jpg|150x150px|alt=Cityscape with two large churches.]] | {{sort|Spain|[[Province of Salamanca]], [[Castile and León]], {{flag|Spain}}
{{coord|40|57|55|N|5|39|52|W|region:ES_type:landmark|name=Old City of Salamanca}}}} | Cultural:
(i)(ii)(iv) | align="center" | — | align="center" | 1988 | Salamanca is important as a university city, as the [[University of Salamanca]], founded in 1218, is the oldest in Spain and among the oldest in Europe. The city was first conquered by the [[Carthage|Carthaginians]] in the 3rd century, and later ruled by the Romans and Moors. The city centre represents [[Romanesque architecture|Romanesque]], [[Gothic architecture|Gothic]], [[Moorish architecture|Moorish]], [[Renaissance architecture|Renaissance]], and [[Baroque architecture]]. {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/381|title=Old City of Salamanca|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=20 December 2011}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Ávila, Spain|Old Town of Ávila]] with its Extra-Muros Churches | [[File:Basilica of San Vicente, Ávila, España.jpg|150x150px|alt=Defensive stone wall with semi-circular towers.]] | {{sort|Spain|[[Province of Ávila]], [[Castile and León]], {{flag|Spain}}
{{coord|40|39|23|N|4|42|0|W|region:ES_type:landmark|name=Old Town of Ávila with its Extra-Muros Churches}}}} | Cultural:
(iii)(iv) | align="center" | — | align="center" | 1985Minor extension of the boundary in 2007. | The [[defensive wall]] surrounding the original town was constructed in the 11th century. It features 82 semicircular towers and 9 gates, and is one of the most complete examples of town walls in Spain. {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/348|title=Old Town of Ávila with its Extra-Muros Churches|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=20 December 2011}} |- ! scope="row" | Old Town of [[Cáceres, Spain|Cáceres]] | [[File:Caceres 11 1 (6623825531).jpg|150x150px|alt=An old town with churches built on a hillside.]] | {{sort|Spain|[[Province of Cáceres]], [[Extremadura]], {{flag|Spain}}
{{coord|39|28|28|N|6|22|12|W|region:ES_type:landmark|name=Old Town of Cáceres}}}} | Cultural:
(iii)(iv) | align="center" | — | align="center" | 1986 | The old town combines [[Roman architecture|Roman]], [[Islamic architecture|Islamic]], Northern [[Gothic architecture|Gothic]], and [[Renaissance architecture|Italian Renaissance]] architectural influences, including more than 30 Islamic towers. {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/384|title=Old Town of Cáceres|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=20 December 2011}} |- ! scope="row" | Old Town of [[Corfu (city)|Corfu]] | [[File:Corfu Old Fortress R14.jpg|150x150px|alt=View over an old town near the sea with a castle.]] | {{sort|Greece|[[Corfu (regional unit)|Corfu]], [[Ionian Islands (region)|Ionian Islands]], {{flag|Greece}}
{{coord|39|37|26|N|19|55|39|E|region:GR_type:landmark|name=Old Town of Corfu}}}} | Cultural:
(iv) | {{convert|70|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}}; buffer zone {{convert|162|ha|abbr=values}} | align="center" | 2007 | The Old [[Corfu (city)|Town of Corfu]], on the [[Island of Corfu]] off the western coasts of [[Albania]] and Greece, is located in a strategic position at the entrance of the [[Adriatic Sea]], and has its roots in the 8th century BC. The three forts of the town, designed by renowned Venetian engineers, were used for four centuries to defend the maritime trading interests of the [[Republic of Venice]] against the [[Ottoman Empire]]. In the course of time, the forts were repaired and partly rebuilt several times, more recently under [[United States of the Ionian Islands|British rule]] in the 19th century. The mainly neoclassical housing stock of the Old Town is partly from the Venetian period, partly of later construction, notably the 19th century. As a fortified Mediterranean port, Corfu’s urban and port ensemble is notable for its high level of integrity and authenticity.{{Cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/978|title=Old Town of Corfu|last=Centre|first=UNESCO World Heritage|website=whc.unesco.org|language=en|access-date=2016-09-08}} {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/978|title=Old Town of Corfu|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=26 June 2010}} |- ! scope="row" | Old Town of [[Segovia]] and its [[Aqueduct of Segovia|Aqueduct]] | [[File:Acueducto Romano (Segovia, España).jpg|150x150px|alt=A three-storied aqueduct running through a town.]] | {{sort|Spain|[[Province of Segovia]], [[Castile and León]], {{flag|Spain}}
{{coord|40|56|54.5|N|4|7|9|W|region:ES_type:landmark|name=Old Town of Segovia and its Aqueduct}}}} | Cultural:
(i)(iii)(iv) | align="center" | — | align="center" | 1985 | The [[Roman aqueduct]] was constructed in the 1st century, the [[medieval architecture|medieval]] [[Alcázar of Segovia|Alcázar]] palace in the 11th century, and the [[Segovia Cathedral|cathedral]] in the 16th. {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/211|title=Old Town of Segovia and its Aqueduct|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=20 December 2011}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Palau de la Música Catalana]] and [[Hospital de Sant Pau]], [[Barcelona]] | [[File:Pavello de Sant Leopold.jpg|150x150px|alt=A large building complex of red stone.]] | {{sort|Spain|[[Province of Barcelona]], [[Catalonia]], {{flag|Spain}}
{{coord|41|23|16|N|2|10|30|E|region:ES_type:landmark|name=Palau de la Música Catalana and Hospital de Sant Pau, Barcelona}}}} | Cultural:
(i)(ii)(iv) | align="center" | — | align="center" | 1997Minor modification of the buffer zone in 2008. | Both buildings were constructed in the early 20th century and designed by [[Lluís Domènech i Montaner]] in the [[modernisme|modernist]] [[Art Nouveau]] movement that was very popular in Barcelona in that period. The two buildings are Montaner's most famous works. {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/804|title=Palau de la Música Catalana and Hospital de Sant Pau, Barcelona|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=20 December 2011}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Paleochristian and Byzantine Monuments of Thessalonika]] | [[File:Saint Demetrius Salonica 4.jpg|150x150px|alt=A church with a square bell tower.]] | {{sort|Greece|[[Thessaloniki (regional unit)|Thessaloniki]], [[Central Macedonia]], {{flag|Greece}}
{{coord|40|38|18|N|22|57|54|E|region:GR_type:landmark|name=Paleochristian and Byzantine Monuments of Thessalonika}}}} | Cultural:
(i)(ii)(iv) | {{convert|5.33|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}} | align="center" | 1988 | Founded in 315 B.C., the provincial capital and sea port of [[Thessalonika]] was one of the first bases for the spread of Christianity. Among its Christian monuments are fine churches, some built on the Greek cross plan and others on the three-nave basilica plan. Constructed over a long period, from the 4th to the 15th century, they constitute a diachronic typological series, which had considerable influence in the [[Byzantine Empire]].{{Cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/456|title=Paleochristian and Byzantine Monuments of Thessalonika|last=Centre|first=UNESCO World Heritage|website=whc.unesco.org|language=en|access-date=2016-09-08}} {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/456|title=Paleochristian and Byzantine Monuments of Thessalonika|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=26 June 2010}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Palmeral of Elche]] | {{center|[[File:Elche Palmeral Duiventoren 02.JPG|150x150px|alt=A forest of palm trees with a city in the background.]]}} | {{sort|Spain|[[Province of Alicante]], [[Valencian Community]], {{flag|Spain}}
{{coord|38|16|10|N|0|41|54|W|region:ES_type:landmark|name=Palmeral of Elche}}}} | Cultural:
(ii)(v) | align="center" | — | align="center" | 2000 | The grove of [[Phoenix dactylifera|date palm trees]] was formally laid out with irrigation systems under the Moors in the 10th century. The palmeral is a rare example of Arab agricultural practices in Europe. {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/930|title=Palmeral of Elche|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=20 December 2011}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Piazza del Duomo, Pisa]] | [[File:Pisa (8189980026).jpg|150x150px|alt=White church, leaning tower and a circular building.]] | {{sort|Italy|[[Pisa|City]] and [[Province of Pisa|Province]] of Pisa, [[Tuscany]], {{flag|Italy}}
{{coord|43|43|23|N|10|23|47|E|region:IT_type:landmark|name=Piazza del Duomo, Pisa}}}} | Cultural:
(i)(ii)(iv)(vi) | {{convert|8.87|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}}; buffer zone {{convert|254|ha|abbr=values}} | align="center" | 1987{{coord|44|52|40|N|15|36|52|E|region:HR_type:landmark|name=Plitvice Lakes National Park}}}} | Natural:
(vii)(viii)(ix) | {{convert|19200|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}} | align="center" | 1979Extended in 2000 by {{convert|10020|ha|abbr=on}} to ensure the integrity of the site. | Over time, water has flown over the natural limestone and chalk, creating natural dams which in turn have created a series of connecting lakes, waterfalls, and caves. The nearby forests are home to bears, wolves and many rare bird species. The site had been listed as [[World Heritage in Danger|endangered]] 1992–1997 due to the potential threat from the [[Croatian War of Independence]]. {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/98|title=Plitvice Lakes National Park|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=26 June 2011}}

(i)(iv) | align="center" | — | align="center" | 1991 | The monastery was founded by the [[Cistercians]] in 1151 and is one of the largest in Spain. It is associated with various royal families in medieval Spain, particularly the [[List of monarchs|kings of the Crown of Aragon]], a composite monarchy of the dynastic union of the Kingdom of Aragon and the County of Barcelona. It is the burial place of the Crown of Aragon monarchs [[Alfonso II of Aragon|Alfonso II]], [[John I of Aragon|John I]], [[John II of Aragon|John II]], [[James I of Aragon|James I]], [[Ferdinand I of Aragon|Ferdinana I]], and [[Peter IV of Aragon|Peter IV]]. {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/518|title=Poblet Monastery|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=20 December 2011}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Porto Venere|Portovenere]], [[Cinque Terre]], and the Islands ([[Palmaria (island)|Palmaria]], [[Tino (island)|Tino]] and [[Tinetto]]) | [[File:Cinque Terre DSC 7064 (14067167400).jpg|150x150px|alt=A coastal town with multi storied colorful houses.]] | {{sort|Italy|[[Province of La Spezia]], [[Liguria]], {{flag|Italy}}

(iii)(iv)(v)(vii)(viii) | {{convert|30639|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}} | align="center" | 1997{{coord|37|41|27|N|26|56|36|E|region:GR_type:landmark|name=Pythagoreion and Heraion of Samos}}}} | Cultural:
(ii)(iii) | {{convert|668|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}}; buffer zone {{convert|402|ha|abbr=values}} | align="center" | 1992 | Many civilizations have inhabited this small [[Aegean island]], near [[Asia Minor]], since the 3rd millennium B.C. The remains of [[Pythagoreion]], an ancient fortified port with Greek and Roman monuments and a spectacular tunnel-aqueduct, as well as the Heraion, [[Heraion of Samos|temple of the Samian Hera]], can still be seen.{{Cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/595|title=Pythagoreion and Heraion of Samos|last=Centre|first=UNESCO World Heritage|website=whc.unesco.org|language=en|access-date=2016-09-08}} {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/595|title=Pythagoreion and Heraion of Samos|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=26 June 2010}} |- ! scope="row" | Renaissance Monumental Ensembles of Úbeda and Baeza | [[File:Iglesia de Santa María de los Reales Alcázares 01.jpg|150x150px|alt=A stone church with one tower.]] | {{sort|Spain|[[Province of Jaén (Spain)|Province of Jaen]], [[Andalusia]], {{flag|Spain}}

(iii) | align="center" | — | align="center" | 1998 | The site includes over 750 examples of [[rock art]] from the late [[prehistory|prehistoric]] period, which feature images ranging from geometric shapes to scenes of men hunting animals. {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/874|title=Rock Art of the Mediterranean Basin on the Iberian Peninsula|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=20 December 2011}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Rock Drawings in Valcamonica]] | [[File:Capodiponte0001.jpg|150x150px|alt=Rock drawing of warriors.]] | {{sort|Italy|[[Province of Brescia]], [[Lombardy]], {{flag|Italy}}

(iv) | align="center" | — | align="center" | 2000 | The walls built to protect the Roman town of Lucus in the 3rd century remain entirely intact and are the best remaining example in Western Europe. {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/987|title=Roman Walls of Lugo|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=20 December 2011}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Way of St. James|Routes of Santiago de Compostela: ''Camino Francés'' and Routes of Northern Spain]] | [[File:Vieira Camino de Santiago.jpg|150x150px|alt=A shell and a drinking bottle.]] | {{sort|Spain|[[Aragon]], [[Navarre]], [[La Rioja (Spain)|La Rioja]], [[Castile and León]] and [[Galicia (Spain)|Galicia]], {{flag|Spain}}
{{coord|42|27|33|N|5|53|0|W|region:ES_type:landmark|name=Route of Santiago de Compostela}}}} | Cultural:
(ii)(iv)(vi) | align="center" | — | align="center" | 1993 | The Route, or the Way of St. James, is a [[pilgrimage]] from the French-Spanish border to the [[Cathedral of Santiago de Compostela]], where the [[Apostle (Christian)|apostle]] [[James, son of Zebedee|James]] is believed to be buried. {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/669|title=Routes of Santiago de Compostela: ''Camino Francés'' and Routes of Northern Spain|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=20 December 2011}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Royal Monastery of Santa María de Guadalupe]] | [[File:Monasterio de Guadalupe.jpg|150x150px|alt=A complex of various buildings including towers made of natural stones.]] | {{sort|Spain|[[Guadalupe, Cáceres|Guadalupe]], [[Province of Cáceres]], [[Extremadura]], {{flag|Spain}}
{{coord|39|27|10|N|5|19|39|W|region:ES_type:landmark|name=Royal Monastery of Santa María de Guadalupe}}}} | Cultural:
(iv)(vi) | align="center" | — | align="center" | 1993 | The monastery is home of [[Our Lady of Guadalupe, Extremadura|Our Lady of Guadalupe]], a [[Shrines to the Virgin Mary|shrine to Mary]] found in the 13th century after being buried from Muslim invaders in 714. The Virgin of Guadalupe and the monastery served as important symbols during the [[Reconquista]], culminating in 1492, the same year as [[Christopher Columbus|Columbus']] discovery of America. The Guadalupe Virgin became an important symbol during the [[evangelization]] of America. {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/665|title=Royal Monastery of Santa María de Guadalupe|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=20 December 2011}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Sacri Monti of Piedmont and Lombardy|''Sacri Monti'' of Piedmont and Lombardy]] | [[File:Sacro Monte di Crea. Cappella del Paradiso3.jpg|150x150px|alt=A circular building on top of a mountain.]] | {{sort|Italy|[[Lombardy]], [[Piedmont]], {{flag|Italy}}
{{coord|45|58|28|N|9|10|10|E|region:IT_type:landmark|name=Sacri Monti of Piedmont and Lombardy}}}} | Cultural:

{{coord|37|40|0|N|23|7|0|E|region:GR_type:landmark|name=Sanctuary of Asklepios at Epidaurus}}}} | Cultural:
(i)(ii)(iii)(iv)(vi) | {{convert|1394|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}}; buffer zone {{convert|3386|ha|abbr=values}} | align="center" | 1988 | In a small valley in the [[Peloponnesus]], the shrine of [[Asklepios]], the god of medicine, developed out of a much earlier cult of [[Apollo]], during the 6th century BC at the latest, as the official cult of the city state of Epidaurus. Its principal monuments, particularly the temple of Asklepios, the Tholos and the Theatre - considered one of the purest masterpieces of Greek architecture – date from the 4th century. The vast site, with its temples and hospital buildings devoted to its healing gods, provides valuable insight into the healing cults of Greek and Roman times.{{Cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/491|title=Sanctuary of Asklepios at Epidaurus|last=Centre|first=UNESCO World Heritage|website=whc.unesco.org|language=en|access-date=2016-09-08}} {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/491|title=Sanctuary of Asklepios at Epidaurus|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=26 June 2010}} |- ! scope="row" | [[San Cristóbal de la Laguna]] | [[File:La Laguna BW 5.JPG|150x150px|alt=A modern plaza with many large trees and a fountain in the middle.]] || align="center" | Spa[[Province of Santa Cruz de Tenerife]],
{{flag|Spain}}

(ii), (iv)|| align="center" | {{convert|60|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}} || align="center" | 1999 || The city contains two centres: the unplanned Upper Town, and the planned Lower Town, laid out according to philosophical principals. Many of the buildings date from the 16th to the 18th centuries.{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/929 |title=San Cristóbal de la Laguna |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=28 May 2010}} |- ! scope="row"| [[City of San Marino|San Marino Historic Centre]] and [[Mount Titano]] | [[File:Monte Titano.jpg|150x150px|alt=Mountain with some rocks and three fortresses on top.]] |{{sort|San Marino|{{flag|San Marino}}

{{coord|42|19|33|N|2|51|54|W|region:ES_type:landmark|name=San Millán Yuso and Suso Monasteries}}}} | Cultural:
(ii)(iv)(vi) | {{convert|19|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}}; buffer zone {{convert|266|ha|abbr=values}} | align="center" | 1997 | The original Suso monastery was founded in the mid-6th century, and is the location where the ''[[Glosas Emilianenses]]'' were written. The codixes are considered the first written examples of the [[Spanish language|Spanish]] and [[Basque language|Basque]] languages, and the monastery is considered the birthplace of written and spoken Spanish. The newer Yuso monastery was built in the 16th century. {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/805|title=San Millán Yuso and Suso Monasteries|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=20 December 2011}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Santiago de Compostela]] (Old Town) | [[File:Cathedral square Santiago de Compostela.jpg|150x150px|alt=A large cathedral with many towers.]] | {{sort|Spain|[[Province of A Coruña]], [[Galicia (Spain)|Galicia]], {{flag|Spain}}
{{coord|42|52|51|N|8|32|41|W|region:ES_type:landmark|name=Santiago de Compostela (Old Town)}}}} | Cultural:
(i)(ii)(vi) | align="center" | — | align="center" | 1985 | The [[Cathedral of Santiago de Compostela]] is the reputed burial-place of the [[Twelve Apostles|apostle]] [[James, son of Zebedee|James]], and is the terminus of the [[Way of St. James]], a [[pilgrimage]] across northern Spain. The town was destroyed by [[Moors|Muslims]] in the 10th century and rebuilt during the following century. {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/347|title=Santiago de Compostela (Old Town)|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=20 December 2011}} |- ! scope="row"| [[Škocjan Caves]] | [[File:Skocjanske jame.jpg|150x150px|alt=Very large entrance to a cave.]] |{{sort|Slovenia|Škocjan pri Divaci, [[Matavun]] and [[Betanja]] in [[Divača]] and [[Sežana]] communes, [[Obalno-kraška statistical region]], {{flag|Slovenia}}

(ii)(iii)(v) | {{convert|1377|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}}; buffer zone {{convert|6403|ha|abbr=values}} | align="center" | 2008 | The Stari Grad Plain is an agricultural landscape that was set up by the [[Colonies in antiquity|ancient Greek colonists]] in the 4th century BC, and remains in use today. The plain is generally still in its original form. The ancient layout has been preserved by careful maintenance of the stone walls over 24 centuries. {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1240|title=Stari Grad Plain|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=26 June 2010}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Stari Ras]] and [[Sopoćani]] | {{center|[[File:Stari Ras.jpg|150x150px|alt=Ruins of a fortress in the mountains.]]}} | {{sort|Serbia|near [[Novi Pazar]], [[Raška District]], {{flag|Serbia}}
{{coord|43|7|8|N|20|25|22|E|region:RS_type:landmark|name=Stari Ras and Sopoćani}}}} | Cultural:
(i)(iii) | {{convert|199|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}}; buffer zone {{convert|9936|ha|abbr=values}} | align="center" | 1979 | On the outskirts of Stari Ras, the first capital of Serbia, there is an impressive group of medieval monuments consisting of fortresses, churches and monasteries. The monastery at Sopoćani is a reminder of the contacts between Western civilization and the Byzantine world. {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/96|title=Stari Ras and Sopoćani|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=26 June 2010}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Stećci]] Medieval Tombstones Graveyards | !style="background-color: #D0E7FF"| {{sort|ZZZ|{{flag|Bosnia and Herzegovina}};

(i)(ii)(iv)(vi) | {{convert|1.16|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}}; buffer zone {{convert|269|ha|abbr=values}} | align="center" | 1986 | The Studenica Monastery was established in the late 12th century by [[Stefan Nemanja]], founder of the medieval Serb state, shortly after his abdication. It is the largest and richest of Serbia’s Orthodox monasteries. Its two principal monuments, the Church of the Virgin and the Church of the King, both built of white marble, enshrine priceless collections of 13th- and 14th-century Byzantine painting. {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/389|title=Studenica Monastery|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=26 June 2010}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Su Nuraxi di Barumini]] | [[File:Su Nuraxi 2.jpg|150x150px|alt=Foundations of former circular buildings.]] | {{sort|Italy|[[Barumini]], [[Province of Medio Campidano]], [[Sardinia]], {{flag|Italy}}

(i)(ii)(iii) | {{convert|20|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}}; buffer zone {{convert|202|ha|abbr=values}} | align="center" | 1986 | This famous temple to the god of healing and the sun was built towards the middle of the 5th century B.C. in the lonely heights of the [[Arcadia]]n mountains. The temple, which has the oldest[[Corinthian capital]] yet found, combines the [[Archaism|Archaic style]] and the serenity of the [[Doric style]] with some daring architectural features.{{Cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/392|title=Temple of Apollo Epicurius at Bassae|last=Centre|first=UNESCO World Heritage|website=whc.unesco.org|language=en|access-date=2016-09-08}} {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/392|title=Temple of Apollo Epicurius at Bassae|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=26 June 2010}} |- ! scope="row" | [[The Cathedral of St James in Šibenik]] | {{center|[[File:StJacobsSibenik.JPG|150x150px|alt=A white church with a dome.]]}} | {{sort|Croatia|[[Šibenik]], [[Šibenik-Knin County]], {{flag|Croatia}}

(i)(ii)(iv) | {{convert|0.10|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}} | align="center" | 2000 | The cathedral is a triple-nave [[basilica]] with three apses and a dome (32 m high inside) and is also one of the most important architectural monument of the [[Renaissance]] in the eastern Adriatic. {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/963|title=The Cathedral of St James in Šibenik|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=26 June 2010}} |- ! scope="row" | [[The Dolomites]] | [[File:Dolomites cablecar view 2009.JPG|150x150px|alt=A rocky mountain landscape.]] | {{sort|Italy|{{flag|Italy}}

(ii)(iv)(vi) | align="center" | — | align="center" | 1999 | The small island of [[Pátmos]] in the [[Dodecanese]] is reputed to be where [[John of Patmos|St John the Theologian]] wrote both his [[Gospel of St John|Gospel]] and the [[Apocalypse]]. A [[Monastery of Saint John the Theologian|monastery dedicated to the ‘beloved disciple’]] was founded there in the late 10th century and it has been a place of pilgrimage and [[Greek Orthodox]] learning ever since. The fine monastic complex dominates the island. The old settlement of Chorá, associated with it, contains many religious and secular buildings.{{Cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/942|title=The Historic Centre (Chorá) with the Monastery of Saint-John the Theologian and the Cave of the Apocalypse on the Island of Pátmos|last=Centre|first=UNESCO World Heritage|website=whc.unesco.org|language=en|access-date=2016-09-08}} {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/942|title=The Historic Centre (Chorá) with the Monastery of Saint-John the Theologian and the Cave of the Apocalypse on the Island of Pátmos|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=12 November 2017}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Sassi di Matera|The Sassi]] and the Park of the Rupestrian Churches of [[Matera]] | [[File:Matera01.jpg|150x150px|alt=Structures built into the rock.]] | {{sort|Italy|[[Matera|City]] and [[Province of Matera|Province]] of Matera, [[Basilicata]], {{flag|Italy}}

(iii) | {{convert|233|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}}; buffer zone {{convert|1936|ha|abbr=values}} | align="center" | 2009 | The Romans built this {{convert|55|m|ft}} [[lighthouse]] on a {{convert|57|m|ft}} rock to mark the entrance to the A Coruña harbor. It is the only fully preserved and functioning Roman lighthouse. {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1312|title=Tower of Hercules|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=20 December 2011}} |- ! scope="row" | University and Historic Precinct of [[Alcalá de Henares]] | [[File:Universidad de Alcala.jpg|150x150px|alt=Plateresque facade of a three storied building.]] | {{sort|Spain|[[Community of Madrid]], {{flag|Spain}}

(ii)(iv)(vi) | align="center" | — | align="center" | 1998 | [[Francisco Jiménez de Cisneros|Cardinal Cisneros]] founded the [[University of Alcalá]] in 1499 and is the first example of the planned university city, serving as a model to other European universities and Spanish missionaries in America. (iii)(v) | {{convert|10789|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}}; buffer zone {{convert|76249|ha|abbr=values}} | align="center" | 2014 | The site covers five wine growing areas as well as Cavour Castle. Wine making has existed in Piedmont since at least the Roman era and has continued since then. The region was also an important trading place between the Etruscans and the Celts and traces of their words still appear in the local dialect. {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1390|title=Vineyard Landscape of Piedmont: Langhe-Roero and Monferrato|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=23 December 2014}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Vizcaya Bridge]] | [[File:Zubia jun.jpg|150x150px|alt=A metal transporter bridge running high above a river in a town.]] | {{sort|Spain|[[Biscay]], [[Basque Country (autonomous community)|Basque Country]], {{flag|Spain}}

(i)(ii) | {{convert|0.86|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}}; buffer zone {{convert|12|ha|abbr=values}} | align="center" | 2006 | The bridge was designed by [[Alberto Palacio]] to cross the [[Nervion]] without disrupting maritime traffic to the [[Port of Bilbao]]. It was built in 1893 and is the world's first [[transporter bridge]]. {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1217|title=Vizcaya Bridge|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=20 December 2011}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Works of Antoni Gaudí]] | [[File:Sagrada Familia 01.jpg|150x150px|alt=A large palace structure with many towers under construction.]] | {{sort|Spain|{{flag|Spain}}

Name change from ''Parque Güell, Palacio Güell and Casa Mila in Barcelona'' to the present name. | The architecture of [[Antoni Gaudí]] is part of the [[Modernisme|Modernist style]], but his designs are described as highly unique. The original listing featured [[Park Güell]], [[Palau Güell]], and [[Casa Milà]]; the 2005 extension added [[Casa Vicens]], the [[crypt]] and nativity façade of [[Sagrada Família]], [[Casa Batlló]], and the crypt at [[Church of Colònia Güell|Colònia Güell]]. {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/320bis|title=Works of Antoni Gaudí |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=20 December 2011}}
